titles: The northern ladd: or, The fair maids choice. Who refus'd all for a plowman, counting her self therein most happy. A country lass who many suitors had, some good, some mean, the worst of them not bad; a weaver, taylor, shoo-maker, first came, vvith many more of ample note and fame: a barber, baker, miller, and the like, yet unto none of those her sails she'd strike: but in a rustick she is only pleas'd, a plowman only has her fancy eas'd. To the tune of, There was a lass in Cumberland, &c.
publisher: Printed for B. [i.e. P.] Brooksby, at the Golden-ball, in West-smithfield.,
notes: Date and place of publication suggested by Wing.
Verse: "I am a lass o'th north country ..."
Item at A5:2[289] imperfect: trimmed affecting imprint.
Reproduction of original in the Harvard University, Houghton Library and the British Library.
